The Story of the Departed One at the Doorpost
They stand at the doorposts
and at the door-hinges;
They stand at the door-frames
after coming to their own home.
When there is plenty of food and drink
and snacks and meals are laid out,
No one remembers them,
because of beings’ kamma.
Thus they give to their relatives
who are compassionate;
Pure, excellent, in a timely way,
suitable food and drink.
‘May this be for your relatives;
may your relatives be happy.’
And there they gather together,
the departed relatives who have come together;
When there is plenty of food and drink,
they respectfully rejoice.
‘May our relatives live long,
for whose sake we receive this;
And we have made an offering,
and the donors are not in vain.’
For there is no agriculture there,
and cattle-rearing is not found;
There is no such trade there,
where one can buy and sell with money;🔽The departed ones who have died there
live on what is given here.
When the rain falls on the mountains,
Just as water flows downhill,
So too what is given here
Benefits the departed.
Just as the full rivers
Fill up the ocean,
So too what is given here
Benefits the departed.
‘He gave to me, he did for me,
He was a relative, friend, or intimate’;
One should give an offering to the departed,
Remembering what was done in the past.
